transcripts.text: What's going on, guys?  It's Josh for Accountability for All, and we're rolling with Joe Orga from Breaking the Flaw.  We're here at the Commonwealth of Mass Department of State Police Troop A. We're practicing our First Amendment rights, our freedom of speech, and we'll see how the cops respond to it.  How's it going?  It's going great.
Yeah, what are you guys up to?
I don't answer questions.  Just filming?  Yeah.
Nothing important?
I don't answer questions.

You don't answer questions?  That's right.  I think it's very important what we're doing.  Oh, okay.  You might not think so, but that's not, your opinion's irrelevant to, because you need to respect what we do.
What do you do?
Well, you'll see.  Okay.  We're going to see like right now or later on?  I'll answer questions.
I'll answer questions.  Okay.  Thanks, man.
All right.  I appreciate it.

Thanks.  Appreciate you.  I couldn't even get out of the car.  There's actually been a ton of corruption with the Mass State Police.  Obviously, that's not all of them, but a ton of issues with the overtime.  I want to ask them about that.  I'm not sure if Joey is aware of that.  What's happening?
He's restricting my first amendment right now.  He's restricting my first... He thinks it's funny.
Patty cake, patty cake, baker's man.
You can't cover both of them.  Oh, you got two hands, so.
Yeah, there you go.  How you going, man?  What's your name?  What's your name, sir?
Can I please have your name and badge number?  No.  Go away.
Why?  Oh, you're refusing to identify yourself?  You're refusing to do anything.
I'm not doing any police action against you.
I'm not identifying myself.  Well, you're required under mass state law to identify yourself by either your badge number or your name or your police ID number.  During police action.
There's no police action.
Actually, that's not correct.  If you're in uniform and serving as a public capacity, I need your supervisor.
I want to talk to your supervisor, please.
Right now, Perry.  Tyrants.
Oh, my shadow can make me see through the door.
Tyrants.  Tyrants.  That's crazy.
Yeah, that's ridiculous.  Instantly censoring our video.  Yeah, not cool.  Here's how we can contact the supervisor.
Okay.  So does it say the supervisor's office?  Ship's command, right?
Yeah.
Yeah, but I think shift command is actually this post here.
Wow.
But I told you that they're bad here, man.
Yeah, this is not right already.  This is right off the bat.  This is not cool.

Yeah, they're dangerous.  Because did you hear about what's going on with all the overtime?  How these guys were on their days off, clocked in, and actually 20 mass state troopers just got fired recently because they were forging overtime.  And it wasn't just regular base cops.  They were on vacation getting paid for detail, getting paid for paternity, clocking in all these extra hours, and actually went up the chain of the command to one of the colonels.  So it doesn't surprise me that this guy's a tyrant.  Yes, sir, I'm requesting your supervisor, Perry.
Yes, please.

Yes.  It's not a request.  I don't work for you.  You work for me.  No, I don't.  I'm not taking orders from you.  Yes, you are.  No, I'm not.  Yes, you are.  Yes, I am.  I pay your salary.  to take action against you.  If you keep this action up, you're going to escalate to disorderly conduct.  I think you're escalating.
We're asking for official business right now, and you're denying us that official business.  I do.  I just requested it.  I just requested it.

I came in here requesting a supervisor.  But if you have something I can actually help you with, I'm more than happy to help you.  So I came in here before I even spoke to you.  The first thing out of my mouth was I needed to speak to a supervisor.  That's my first issue.  I would like to speak to a supervisor.  My second issue happened during the confrontation because I just asked for your name.  And secondly...
No, I know exactly what you're doing.

You're coming in to make a stick.  No, I have a constitutionally protected activity to film public employees in the course of their duties.  I'm not swearing.  Yeah, outside in public.  No, this is a private building?
This is.
No, this is private.  Inside here it is.  This is private property.  Right here, right here.
That's if I step outside in that area.
I can't trust past what my eyes can see, sir.  Can I speak to your supervisor?
I want to speak to your supervisor.
Yes.
Don't scream, because they get fired.  Well, you put that thing down, so I
had to escalate my voice a little bit
to get through to that blocking noise.
Here it comes.
Hey, guys.  How are you?
Pleasure to meet you.
Doesn't matter.

What can I do for you?  Well, we just came in here to just take some pictures, to take some film.  And we don't have any ill will.  We're in a public space.  And I just approached the glass because I wanted to speak to a supervisor just so I could get some information as to what goes on here, how the police differ a little bit from local police.  He refused to identify himself.  He told me that I was not allowed to, it's a public space, so I was not allowed to film him back there.  And I explained to him that I can't trespass what my eyes can see.  And he said on film, and I'd like to file a complaint, because he said, well, if you don't get out of here, now you're making a stink.  I'll escalate this, and I'll find an excuse to get you for disorderly conduct.

Okay, so here's, I can answer everything that you brought to my issue.  Thank you.  My attention.  First of all, you're welcome to come in here.  Thank you.  There's no problem with that.  One thing I am going to be very honest with, yes, this is a public building.  You have the right to come in here.  The only reason I would be concerned with this is obviously for safety.  And the reason I mean by this is our safety.  And hear me out.  I will listen to you.
You will listen to me.  Absolutely.

The reason I say this is obviously with Al Qaeda and ISIS and stuff like that, of people taking pictures of public buildings, That's a serious issue.  I don't know what your gentlemen, what your thoughts are or whatever.  Are you trying to get, you know, see our security system and have nefarious actions?  May I ask you something?
Go ahead.  Are we able from this public space or any public spaces around the building able to visualize any of that restricted access that you're talking about?  No.  So why are you concerned?
I'm just concerned for our safety and well-being.
I actually do understand.
Right now, no, I don't.

I do understand what you're saying from a police perspective.  You're saying that with some of the tragic events that are happening in the world, there is secure information here, and I do respect that concern.  It makes sense, Lieutenant.  My issue is going to be that if I didn't come in here with a camera, okay, and I just came in here with my eyes and I'm just standing in the lobby, it wouldn't be a concern, and my camera is an extension of my eyes, and I cannot trespass if my eyes can see.  I have no problem with cameras.  I'm not going to go into any restricted areas.  I'm not going to try and interfere in any of your police business.  And if there are victims that come in or out, my intention is not to film them.  I could if I wanted to.  It would be a request, but I'm not going to.  My main issue right now is that Officer Perry, and I only know that because I had to look through the glass, he refused to identify himself.  And he said that he was going to escalate it because I feel like the police job should be to de-escalate.  He should – he wants to escalate it and he'll find – now we're making a stink and he'll find a reason to come up with an excuse for disorderly conduct.
And I would like – I mean that's a – that's a – That's a serious charge for peaceful people that you find no threat for him to say something like that.
Because you have the guns.  I have a camera.  You can shoot me with a bullet.  I can only shoot you with film.
Amen.  As far as that going, I'm going to give you the three options that you do have.  And, again, you get it on video, so this can't be twisted.
Because, again, you have to understand.
We're not going to add it out.  We're not going to twist you away.  Absolutely.
Because I'm the most honest.  Hey, I'm the most honest and easy, which I really appreciate, de-escalating.  Right now we have things may be a little bit hot today.
I think he just doesn't want to... I'll be honest.  I'm not going to go in there and apologize to him.  It's kind of an exertion of power.

But here's the thing, and this is what you guys are aiming at, and I agree.  That's why we have... the form, the citizen complaint form, and I truly think that you should do that.  Okay.  I'm being honest.  I have nothing to say.
So then your suggestion is vote the complaint.
Can I ask, what's the follow-up on that?  So, like, if we file a complaint?
They're going to contact you, and they're going to interview you.  Not us.  It's obviously going to be...
Well, isn't that the United Street, maybe, or like...
No, no, no, no, no.  Division of Standards and Trails.

Oh, okay.  So could you just please, and then I'll leave you.  I know the major is looking for you.  Could you please produce me with his name and his badge number since he did fail to identify.  I can't fill out the form blank.  And I thank you for your time.
Correct.  It was Trooper Perry.  Trooper Perry.  Out of state police standards.

Okay, so I just write Trooper Perry.  I don't need a badge number or anything.  State police standards.  We all have numbers and everything like that.  Is there a pen that they can let me use while I fill it out?
No, no, no, no, no.  Take it with you.
Trust me, it's... All right.
What I want you to do, because I don't think it's here, but I'm going to write it down for you.
Okay.
As I said, it's the SP-340, and it's obviously citizens' complaint.  And you're here at state police standards.  Great.  And... I am going to give you my name and ID.
I really appreciate that.
Absolutely.
Lieutenant Harvey, thank you very much.  We appreciate you defending our freedoms and honoring your oath.
Thank you, sir.  Thank you.
Thank you.  You were very kind.

You know what?  For 32 years, I've been in law enforcement, and I've... And I've listened to what you just said 100 million times, and it never gets old.  Because still, I pride myself on doing the right thing and representing the state police.  Because, again, right now, as you said, it's tough.  Not everything needs to be adversarial.  And you know what?  Hopefully you're going to leave here today going, hey, you know what?  That Mike Harvey, what a nice guy.  And now maybe you'll get the next police officer, if you have a bad interaction, hopefully.
You said do the right thing.  Yes, sir.  What if the law is wrong?  Will you still do the right thing?
What do you mean?
So the law – you guys are law enforcers.
What if the law is wrong?  What if the law says that it's violating someone's rights in the constitutional sense?  Will you still enforce those laws?
I have to.  I have to.
Sir, may I remind you that you swore in the Constitution that Trump's all laws, even if there's a law passed, may contradict it.
You're 100% right, but we have – Thank you.  But we have – The safeguards in place.
I don't click bait.  I'm not going to do anything crazy.  It's going to be 100%.
No, my job doesn't allow me to open up stuff like that.  Do you know what I'm saying?
It's on YouTube, yeah.  I don't know if you can just hit the link on your phone or anything.
So I'm at pol.state.

Officer Perry, I just want to let you know that your lieutenant did an excellent job today.  And although you escalated the situation, he did a great job at de-escalating the situation.
